Seizure.-1° It is essential that an action for recovery of objects seized should be brought against all having an interest therein, and the execution debtor must be made a party even when he is a minor, for he can be legally represented by others.

2° The owner of a movable seized and sold by public auction cannot revindicate it from the purchaser at the auction who has acted in good faith, for the judicial sale constitutes a just title for such purchaser. His only recourse is against the debtor to whose assets the price has been added. If the purchase money has not been distributed among the creditors, he has no privilege and can only rank with them pari passu. If it has been distributed among the creditors, or handed over to the execution creditor, he has no recourse against any of them, the only exception being where the execution creditor has acted in bad faith, in which case the owner has a recourse, on general principles, for the price and damages.
Fruits of a tree when seized follow the rules applicable to movable property.

Service of judgment (In criminal proceedings).- 1° The appeal a minima of the State Representative from a judgment of conviction by default, must be suspended if the person convicted has not been personally served with the judgment, since he has the right of making opposition to such judgment, service on the Parquet not being sufficient.

2° No special provision having been made by the C. Cr. Pr. for service of judgments in case of the absence or domicile unknown of the person to be served, the rules of civil procedure should be applied.

The Governor or Chef de Parquet served in this way has the duty cast on him of searching for the person to be served and informing him of the service, and the rule of civil procedure, that opposition may be made against judgments by default up to the time that the defaulting party has knowledge of their execution, should be applied in criminal matters, it being of public policy for no one to be convicted definitely until he has had an opportunity of defending himself.
Accordingly, a person against whom a judgment of conviction by default has been served on the Parquet, preserves his right of opposition until the execution of the judgment.

3º Opposition to criminal judgments by default is, in the absence of special provisions, governed by the rules of civil procedure. A person who has been convicted by default and condemned to a term of imprisonment may consequently make opposition to the judgment until such time as he may become aware of its existence. If he be without any known domicile, the service of the judgment previously made on the Parquet will not affect his rights.

Servitude of view.-Apertures made in the wall of a house do not give rise to any right of servitude over the neighbouring tenement, however long they may have been in existence. The owner possesses the right to make them as an incident of the unrestricted enjoyment of his own property.
His neighbour cannot prevent him from making them but may, on the other hand, in the exercise of his own right of ownership, erect buildings which obstruct such apertures.

Robbery with violence.-1° Violence as an aggravating circumstance of theft consists in the employment of forcible means to overcome the victim's power of resistance, in order to facilitate the theft.

A theft committed after the administration of narcotics to the victim in order to enable the thief to steal without encountering opposition is robbery with violence, and must be distinguished from the case of theft from a person in a natural sleep. The latter is a case of simple theft, since the victim's condition renders the theft possible, while in the former case, the thief has deliberately attempted, by the administration of narcotics to the victim, to prevent him from offering any resistance.

It follows that, in this last alternative, the vendor cannot refuse to pay back the portion of the purchase money which he has received, on the ground that he will require it to meet the hypothecary charges made by the purchaser.

Sale with right of redemption.-1° A contract for the sale of land with right of redemption is to be construed as a contract of pledge if the circumstances be such as to indicate that the intention of the parties was merely to constitute a security for the repayment of a debt. Such circumstances would be (1) the inadequacy of the purchase money (2) that the purchaser did not enter into possession of the thing sold (3) that he let it at a high rent to the vendor and (4) that it is agreed that the right of redemption should only be forfeited on failure to pay the rent.
2° According to Art. 338 of the C.C., any sale made with a reservation of a right for the vendor to recover the thing sold, is deemed to be a sale with right of redemption.

The rule of Egyptian law for the construction of agreements is to be found in Art. 138 of the C.C., which lays down that every agreement, whatever may be the literal meaning of the terms used, must be construed according to the purpose which the parties had in view, the nature of the contract and custom.

Oath (Decisive and supplementary).-A party who tenders or tenders back the oath to the other party, who accepts it, is bound by a judicial contract. He is therefore not allowed to establish the falsity of the oath in order to annul the judgment based on the oath, or to set aside the judicial contract, by bringing an action directly before the correctional tribunal. His only remedy is to denounce the matter to the Parquet.

On the other hand, when the oath has been tendered by order of the Court, since there is in this case no judicial contract, the party injured by the falsity of the oath can institute proceedings as civil claimant directly before the correctional tribunal.

Oral evidence.-1° A condition in an obligation for 400 piastres, that the debtor can only claim to be liberated on obtaining the document itself or else a receipt sealed by the creditor, and that oral evidence shall not be admitted, must be held to be valid. The law, in distrust of oral evidence, has fixed a limit for its admissibility. In the cases in which the law allows it, it is in the interrest of the parties, and they can waive this benefit.

2° An agreement in a note for P.T. 500 that discharge of the obligation should be proved by writing only and that oral evidence should be of no value, should be upheld as it is not contrary to public policy.
3° When in a contract, even of a commercial nature, it is agreed that payment shall only be proved by the return of the document or by a written receipt, oral evidence of payment cannot be given.

Ownership (Joint).—The sale by one co-owner of a portion of the property held in undivided shares cannot confer upon the purchaser any greater rights over the portion sold than his vendor himself possessed.

It follows that the other owners may obtain a declaration, to the extent of their share, that they are co-owners of the portion sold, and that the sale is void as regards their shares. The judgment so obtained has no effect on the validity of the sale as between the purchaser and vendor, and full effect will be given to the sale if the portion sold falls to the vendor's share as the result of a partition.

Malicious wounding of animals. — The reason for visiting the offence of maliciously wounding a beast of burden with a severer penalty when committed at night is that the darkness affords facilities for committing the act and for the escape of the offender. Night is in this case to be taken to mean actual darkness. The offence is consequently not aggravated through being committed by night, if, although it was committed after sunset, the darkness was not, in fact, of such intensity as to facilitate the perpetration of the offence or to increase the difficulty of arresting the culprit.

Mandate.- Payment of a debt to a person who falsely represents himself as agent of the creditor does not discharge the debtor, since he might have required production of an official copy of the alleged mandate to receive payment. Payment so made is, as regards the creditor, “Res inter alios acta," but the debtor may recover from the person guilty of the misrepresentation.
(Trib. App. Kena, 12 Vay 1903; Vo. 53, II, p. 35.)

Mandate (Proof).-When the sum involved exceeds P.T. 1,000, mandate must be proved by documentary evidence. But where the Cadi, acting in his notarial capacity, draws up a deed of conveyance, a statement which he has set out in accordance with the testimony of witnessess to the effect that one of the parties to the deed is mandatary of a third person, is not admissible as such evidence,

Novation.—Novation is not presumed but must result from an express declaration. Consequently, the intention to make novation cannot be inferred from the fact that the debtor has given to his creditor a promissory note for the sum due to the latter in virtue of a previous agreement, Therefore the sureties who guaranteed the discharge of such agreement are still liable to the creditor.

2° The summary court has no jurisdiction to try the case of a person accused of abuse of confidence when he has been previously convicted and sentenced on two occasions to a year's imprisonment.

Jurisdiction (ratione loci).— The object of making election of domicile, in a contract, is to attribute jurisdiction to the Courts of the place designated by the parties for the trial of disputed questions arising out of its performance. Such election must be made in unambiguous terms and is not to be inferred from a clause merely indicating the place of payment; this being inserted in view only of the amicable performance of the contract.

Jurisdiction of Markaz Tribunals.—The offence of unlawfully killing a sheep is punishable, not under Art. 312 but under Art. 310 P.C., a sheep not being a domestic animal. The Markaz Tribunals have consequently no jurisdiction to deal with the case.
(Markaz Trib. of Nuga Hamadi, 30 May 1905; No. 107, p. 77.)

Jurisdiction of Native Tribunals.-1° In order that a local subject may be treated as a foreigner from the point of view of the jurisdiction of the Native Tribunals, it is not sufficient that he should produce a consular certificate stating that he enjoys foreign protection. He should prove that the Government has consented to his change of nationality, or at any rate, that the Government has recognised that he is not amenable to the jurisdiction of the Native Tribunals.

2º Art. 7 of the Decree of 22 February 1894, exempting the State from all liability for any damage resulting from the steps taken by the Irrigation Department, is not applicable in case of damage caused by acts which are contrary to law and equity, or which infringe upon private rights when such acts are not necessary in the public interest.

The Native Courts, having jurisdiction to deal with all actions which seek to make the State liable for executive acts done in violation of the law and decrees, can decide any claim for indemnity by reason of the violation of the law relating to dykes and canals.

Jurisdiction of Summary Tribunals.-1° The Summary Tribunal has Jurisdiction for the trial of incidents of an urgent nature relating to the execution of a judgment. Since the law has not laid down any rule whereby the urgency of such incidents may be determined, the judge is free to appreciate the circumstances of each case and to hold it to be urgent or not as he, in the exercise of his discretion, may deem fit.

The fact that it is sought to execute the judgment against a person who was not a party to the suit and the possibility that immediate execution may effect irreparable injury, are circumstances amounting to urgency, giving Law (Citation).— v. Lawful defence ( Conditions),—The conditions necessary for lawful defence are: (1) that no more force should be employed than is required to repel the act of aggression, and (3) that such act should constitute one of the offences mentioned in Art. 210 P.C.

Lawful defence can be successfully pleaded to a charge of assault on a person who, having endeavoured to intrude into apartments reserved for women and having refused to leave when duly ordered to do so, had to be expelled by force.

Lease.-1° The principal landlord has a privilege over the crops and movables of the sub-lessee, but the extent of his right differs according as sub-letting is allowed or prohibited. In the former case, the right is limited to the amount of the rent of the sub-lease, if unpaid, or such part thereof as remains unpaid at the time that seizure is effected. This results from the landlord's right to proceed directly against the sub-lessee. In the

In the event of no tax being due, the Court will appoint an expert for the purpose of fixing its value. If, on the contrary, the immovable is assessed, the Court may not go behind the valuation based upon an existing tax by nominating an expert to ascertain whether such valuation be correct or not.

Jurisdiction of Civil Tribunals.—The Courts enumerated by the Decree of 18 May 1892 have sole jurisdiction for the trial of causes in which natives sue the Government, either singly, or together with one, or more, co-defendants.

Jurisdiction of Court of Appeal.- The Court of appeal is empowered to modify the qualification of the offence, provided, however, that, in so doing it does not alter its nature as judged in first instance. (Cass. 25 February 1905; No. 84, p. 65.)

Jurisdiction of Criminal Tribunals.-1°The power given to the judge, when ordering an acquittal, to determine the damages which the parties can claim from one another, is not intended to enable a civil action to be brought before a criminal court merely because such a course might be more favourable to the claimant. Consequently the judge has power when acquitting, to declare the civil action inadmissible if he thinks that the principal issue in the criminal proceedings is purely civil, or that it requires special proceedings for its proof.

20 The terms “judge” “judge of first instance” and “judge of appeal” have a general meaning and are equivalent to “ Tribunal” or “ Court” whatever máy be the number of judges sitting. “Judge” in Art. 50 P.C. is accordingly to be taken in a general sense.
In principle, criminal penalties can only be pronounced by courts having criminal jurisdiction.
An offence is a crime, misdemeanour, or police offence, according as the law makes it punishable by one of the penalties applicable to these three classes respectively.

Although the penalty of penal servitude provided by Art. 50 P.C. is not obligatory, the judge having the option of inflicting this penalty or imprisonment, such option can only be exercised by a judge having criminal jurisdiction, that is, by the criminal Court.

3º Although the antecedent is not an element of the offence, yet the penalty entailed in consequence of its existence affects the jurisdiction on the analogy of Art. 179 C.Cr. Pr. where the appellate jurisdiction is affected by the sentence given.

Moreover the law defines crimes as acts punishable by (inter alia) penal servitude for a term, and the court of first instance has jurisdiction in such cases, so that Art. 50 P.C. allows the infliction of a penalty which it is not in the power of a summary judge to give. “Judge” in Art. 50 P.C. should be understood in its general sense of "Tribunal” or “court," whatever the number of judges therein.
4º Criminal Courts have exclusive jurisdiction, except in certain cases, for the trial of questions incidental to the principal issue before them.

An accused person cannot, therefore, pending the prosecution, bring an action before the civil court for the purpose of obtaining judgment upon a question which forms part of his defence to the criminal charge. The urgency of such question does not affect this rule.
(Sum. Trib. Tel El Barud, August 1904; No. 70, p.48.)

3° The case of a person accused of theft, with six previous convictions for that offence, including a sentence to a year's imprisonment, must be considered as a crime, and the Summary court is incompetent to deal therewith.

Cassation (Admissibility).-1° The accused cannot avail himself in cassation of the ground that his application to the appeal tribunal was out of time, the appeal being in his interest.

2º Where a Court has misapplied a provision of the law, its judgment of conviction will nevertheless be upheld if, in the appeal in Cassation by the accused persons, it appear that they have suffered no prejudice. A judgment convicting for voluntary homicide, but erroneously pronouncing the penalty for assault resulting in death, is therefore not liable to cassation, on the appeal of the accused, since the latter penalty is less severe than that which should have been pronounced.

3º Appeal in cassation is only admissible against a final judgment on the merits. Accordingly it is inadmissible when lodged against a judgment given on a plea of objection and naming a later day for the pleadings on the general issue.

4° When a civil claimant to whom damages have been awarded in first instance dies after judgment in first instance and before the hearing of the appeal and the accused does not on the hearing of the appeal seek to avail himself of such death, the fact that the appellate tribunal has confirmed the judgment so awarding damages is not a ground for cassation.
5° Only judgments which are final as regards the party appealing are susceptible of being reviewed by the Court of Cassation.

Cassation (Misapplication of law).—The law has not determined any limit of time within which the previous convictions entailing the application of Art. 50 P.C. must have been pronounced, the last conviction alone being subject to prescription.

An appeal in cassation will therefore lie from a judgment declaring this article inapplicable on the ground that convictions prior to the last penalty incurred by a recidivist are more than five years old.

Cassation (Substantial nullity of judgment).—1° A judgment is not liable to cassation for failure to mention the dates of previous convictions, when the existence of such convictions has not, in fact, led to an increase in the penalty pronounced.

2° For the application of Art. 50 P.C., it is not required that the previous convictions should have been within a certain period of time, but such convictions with their dates should be mentioned in the judgment, in order to prevent it being liable to cassation for not stating the facts of the case.

3° An a; peal lodged by the civil claimant only does not prevent a judgment of acquittal from acquiring the force of “res judicata.” Under such circumstances, the judgment of the Court of Appeal, awarding damages to the civil claimant, is governed by the principles of civil law. Such a judgment is not therefore, liable to cassation on any of the following grounds:
1. That it fails to mention the text of the articles of the Penal Code which it purports to apply.
2. That it does not mention the date of the offence.
3. That it does not state to which category of punishable acts the offence belongs.
